thread.title: Joe Kennedy speaks to NAACP members of hope during ‘dark and difficult’ Trump era
thread.title_full: Joe Kennedy speaks to NAACP members of hope during ‘dark and difficult’ Trump era - The Boston Globe

author: bostonglobe
title: Joe Kennedy speaks to NAACP members of hope during ‘dark and difficult’ Trump era

organizations.name: national association for the advancement of colored people chapter

text:
Google+
Paul Sancya/Associated Press
US Representative Joseph P. Kennedy III in July 2016.
By Amanda Hoover Globe Correspondent February 25, 2017
CAMBRIDGE — US Representative Joseph P. Kennedy III assured a crowd packing a Central Square church Saturday morning that President Trump’s administration will not rewrite the “American story,” as he encouraged the group to stand together in the face of potential oppression.
“We gather this morning in some dark and difficult times,” Kennedy said, listing actions on the part of the Trump administration that have stoked anxieties in some communities, such as criticism of the press, the stalled immigration order, a potential rollback of LGBT protections, and controversial Cabinet nominees such as Attorney General Jeff Sessions.
Advertisement
“For all that gather here today, this is a deeply personal fight,” he said, recalling the battle civil rights leaders waged locally and nationally. “It is our story. It cannot be rewritten, for it is sheltered in every American heart.”
More than 200 people gathered in a room adjacent to the St. Paul A.M.E. Church to hear remarks from leaders of the local National Association for the Advancement of Colored People chapter, Cambridge Mayor E. Denise Simmons, and Kennedy, the event’s keynote speaker. During a brunch that celebrated the life of Martin Luther King Jr. and raised funds for the NAACP, community members seeking solidarity and solutions came together to discuss voting rights, immigration, and protections for the LGBT community and religious and racial minorities.
Get Fast Forward in your inbox: Forget yesterday's news. Get what you need today in this early-morning email. Sign The event was the first Cambridge NAACP gathering held since 2015, after a year of dormancy and a change in leadership, said Richard Harding, the chapter’s vice president and a committee member of Cambridge Public Schools.
“This event is the rebirth of the branch,” Harding said, noting that the brunch sold out.
“In a post-Trump era, the NAACP is as important as ever,” he said.
Advertisement
The congressman spoke about how people who oppose the Trump agenda can come together to stand up for marginalized citizens and those whose rights have been threatened by some of the executive orders signed by the president.
“You’ve never had the luxury of taking our country’s protections for granted,” Kennedy said. “Every time we say ‘black lives matter,’ we strive for a day when our country doesn’t need to be reminded that a segment of our population counts.”
Kennedy’s speech drew a warm response from the crowd, who applauded and cheered as they sat around tables draped with blue tablecloths and gold napkins, the colors of the NAACP logo.
“The only way this mission is going to move forward is if you have more people like him,” said Andrea Collymore, 53, an educator who lives in Cambridge.
Others took advantage of the opportunity to support the organization financially.
“I essentially came to support the NAACP,” said Marvin Robinson, 64, who teaches in South Boston and lives in Lower Mills in Dorchester. “I thought I might hear some things that might inspire me and connect me to others.”
Speaking after Kennedy, Simmons encouraged the crowd to remember the progress minority communities made under former president Barack Obama, and to remain vigilant in the coming years.
‘’
“I know we’re all getting a bit weary of this constant assault on our community,” she said, speaking after Kennedy. “We have gone from eight years of progress . . . to suddenly wake up to a nightmare.”
“This too shall pass,” she added. “It does have an expiration date — [but] not soon enough.”
For some, the turnout, as well as Kennedy’s words, brought hope.
“I just thought the program was wonderful — to hear Joe Kennedy, to see all the activism,” said Margo Attles, 50, a physician’s assistant from Cambridge.
“It motivated me to be reminded that like Mayor Simmons said, it’s a brief time, and this too shall pass.”
Amanda Hoover can be reached at amanda.hoover@globe.com .
